comments.commentBody: That dude hardly needs an invitation, he very enthusiastically and readily will do that himself. As far as if he was a used-car salesman I still don't know, my only guess would be yes.

so I take it - and I was informed by some commenters here - that the man who looked like a retired Used-car-salesman, who sat opposite of Obama "before" the Superbowl game started - was a dude called O'Reilly?

And supposedly he is a man who works for this American TV-channel for retirees.
And supposedly Obama invited this dude to make a complete fool of himself -(including acting REALLY creepy!)

Now why didn't neither Mrs Collins nor Mr. Brooks mention that Obama did this "very good"!

I think you need to go to the Afghan Mujaheddin, nurtured by and prepared by the CIA, Saudi Intelligence and the ISI. The fruit we are eating in the form of Al Qaeda and similar terrorist are from the Afghan War. Yes we defeated the Soviets but at what cost?
G W may have put a finer focus on the mess but he did not start it.

It is not just Egypt, most so call Muslim majority countries are in turmoil, exceptions being the instigators and supporters of these groups. Look at Pakistan, Afghanistan, Libya, Syria, Indonesia, Malaysia, Iraq, and Egypt to name a few and then look at the Snakes head Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Qatar, UAE, and Jordan. It is only a matter of time Chicken will come home to roost. The same way as the Jihadis who went from the West to Syria are coming back home as hardened criminals.
In order to crush this movement we need to stop the funding source; the primary funding source is Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and UAE. They are sending funds to western institutions too along with their terroristic Wahhabi ideology.

I think you missed my point. The issue isn't whether one has enough confidence to say "no" to people every time he or she is invited out for coffee or pizza. What I pointed out is that many students in college, especially those who have been crowded out of Federal Work Study jobs, do not even have the option to participate in such activities because of a lack of funds. I am concerned that due to financial reasons, students won't have the chance to become part of a social group. That, in turn, leads them become unhappy, and as we all know, unhappy students are more likely to leave the institution they are attending.

Your daughter has been incredibly fortunate (and, I assume, not undeservedly so). But, she has had the opportunity of a great support system that embraced her in the form of ROTC and a sorority. My concern is for the students who don't have such systems. If one (important) way for these students to build a social group includes hanging out or doing things that require money, colleges placing an extra squeeze on these students will only serve to hamper important social interactions.
Why, because Honda is so determinedly non-disruptive, i.e., complaisant?  That's faint praise.

I don;t watch him much as he is not my cup of tea but Fallon is genuinely talented while Jay is not. Jay has skills like a good character actor he know how to deliver other peoples jokes and that is it.

NBC really blew it over the last several years, didn't they? Didn't the Today show have much of the same angst about who gets to do what? How did they manage to lose "Must-See TV"?

Jay Leno ruined the Tonight Show with his shenanigans over getting it and keeping it. His behavior towards Conan O'Brien was rude and underhanded. Why didn't he spend as much energy working on his material as he did preventing anyone else with a better act from getting the job?

Fallon seems like just the sort of uninspired wet noodle to mop up the debris left over from Leno's run.

Leno is beloved by millions of well-to-do Boomers and retired people. He can write his own ticket. He will likely do some stand-up comedy tours for awhile, then get a late-night show on one of the cable networks, while simultaneously doing a long-standing run at a major venue in Las Vegas. The man is a money-earning machine. I was always a Letterman guy, but Leno on Letterman in the 1980s was a delightful combination. He isn't going anywhere, he is merely changing channels.
I never understood why some people are so obsessed with hipsters. Are you a square or something?

I never understood why hipsters so desperately wanted Leno to fail; for all their pretense to hating racism and sexism, wanting to help humanity, they do not like people unlike them very much.

This is the rare article in the NY press to admit that Conan never outdrew Leno. Like Lena Dunham, he is a 2 city sensation--and not even all zip codes within those cities.
We should be proud and reassured that tech titans have assimilated and strive for their favored political candidates' victories the old fa$hioned way.
The daughter was quick to politicize it. “We would be very angry if this got used for the gun control lobby."
So you're basically implying the guy in this article is an outlier regarding gun safety? Or maybe he should've had a retention holster? Now who's blaming the victim?

But gang-related violence, from what I have read, accounts for only about 12% of all homicides. Yet, anecdotally, I would say at least 50% of the comments I read after shootings is why are no liberal gun-grabbers going after gangs in Chicago? Do you not think there might be SOME reason for a "gross characterization" when the very same people are encouraging the statements you claim they aren't making?

I think the point is, the gun did absolutely nothing to save this man. In fact, he was killed with his own weapon. I don't this is a question of using the example to blame the victim, just that contrary to the gun right mantra - more guns means less crime - this victim's possession of the gun didn't make him safer.

Your logic is sound, but you have no sources cited.

It would all depend on the mental preparation of the shooter. Someone who has little or no confidence with a firearm in stressful situations (most police, nearly all private citizens) would be more likely to suffer PTSD.

Shooters with considerable mental preparation, like military special forces and snipers, are highly unlikely to suffer PTSD.

That all being said, if I have to choose, I would rather be prepared than traumatized.
US public policy has plainly encouraged many writers here to have guns and dwell upon shooting people constantly.

The common denominator here is not guns it is mans inhumanity to man. The human race was killing, maiming and writing OpEd pieces way before guns arrived on the scene.

If you are angry with your brother it is the same as murder.
Jesus

Actually, rates of depression and suicide run higher among those who have never been deployed. In combat, people may try to kill our soldiers, but our soldiers tend to employ their training and equipment to good effect, and empower themselves to the detriment of our enemies.

People who are powerless, on the other hand, are virtually guaranteed to get PTSD when traumatized.

New Yorkers tend to live in fear, and have since at least the time of the Kitty Genovese murder during the era when the crime rate skyrocketed.

By and large, only the Mayor, plus the rich, and powerful, have access to armed security guards and/or guns for self defense. Even carrying a small knife might result in arrest during an extra-constitutional, "stop and frisk".

So, in that regards, this blog merely preaches to the choir. Because, as is often said, misery loves company.
The deliberate creation of stress seems to be as American as apple pie. I think it is considered essential to the post-slavery economy.

Your opening vignette proves again how clueless some liberal researchers are:

PTSD is a reaction to circumstances which threaten your life. Generally speaking, the more control you had over the circumstances, the better you manage the stress.

Therefore, civilians getting caught in gang violence, who have little control, would be at very high risk for PTSD. Even gang members are largely not capable of controlling the dangers to their lives. Car accident and fall victims, however, have much more ability to deal with such dangers, so they would be at lower risk for PTSD.

Soldiers are trained to cope with and defeat both stress and physical threats. People with practice at staying alive tend to be much better at it, both in physical and mental senses.

It makes me wonder a bit, are you afraid of being victimized? Do you feel helpless at the thought of threats you can't control?

If so, you need professional help, from someone who can teach you self defense (armed or unarmed) and other empowering skills. Otherwise you will live in fear.
And, I forgot to add, on account of being (1) white and (2) male.

@hh

You say you want a revolution
Well, you know
We all want to change the world
You tell me that it's evolution
Well, you know
We all want to change the world
But when you talk about destruction
Don't you know that you can count me out

@Clairette,

I am sure that Major Andre was happy to know that General Washington would order a hanging, but no drawing and quartering.

I am only surprised that Benedict Arnold didn't stick around to explain himself to Washington.

A central issue for anyone over 40 (and especially those over 55) is not only the cost of health insurance, but the availability of health insurance in the individual market.  Got diabetes?  Got heart disease?  Got cancer?  Then basically forget finding health insurance prior to the ACA.  Guaranteed-issue means you can leave your employer-based coverage behind and still get coverage.  For 60-somethings with medical conditions, this is an incredible blessing, even if they never receive a dime in assistance from the government.  Believe me, there are millions of people who work demanding jobs and will gladly retire before they are Medicare-eligible.  These people do not need subsidies, but do need a risk pool that they can join.  The ACA makes that possible.  There's nothing evil about letting a sick person retire at age 60, rather than suffer a heart attack while sitting in the next cubicle (which happened to my 45-year-old colleague in 2008).

@Clairette Rose,

I really cant say how the Latin Kings obtain their weapons not being a member of that civic organization.

King George may be gone but there are other politicians who think they can rule by decree.

Tim,
The Supreme Court is not without their prejudices, and several of the members are in the pocket of the NRA.

@Tim McCoy --

Did you not read the history and factual account I posted yesterday, detailing the current role and purpose of the NRA, and where the real money comes from and where it goes?

I find it ironic that you, who rage about government intervention in our lives, place such confidence in the disputed 5-4 decision of SCOTUS on DC v Heller -- you appear to have more faith in the views of 5 men, whose colleagues vehemently disputed their views, than you do in any other governmental action -- only, I think, because that one decision supports your view of your unfettered rights to guns anywhere and everywhere.

HDNY,

Do you have any evidence to substantiate your claim about SCOTUS justices, who enjoy lifetime appointments without review, election, or other threats to independence, being in the NRA pocket? Or is that just another in invention of the anti-gun crowd. "Common sense", if they disagree with you, they must have been bought off?

It should be no surprise that victims of gunshots in hospitals suffer some degree of PTSD's, a bullet from a Taliban isn't any different than one from a crazy husband or boyfriend or an angry neighbor or…but we should not be concerned with that we are too busy defending the NRA interpretation of the second amendment.

Steve, what's your point?

I strongly suspect those who have used a gun in justifiable self-defense would have suffered much more than PTSD if they didn't have the gun.

My wife, stopping two rapists with a gun, is certainly glad she scared them off rather than enduring a rape . . .
Yet you somehow had no problem "comprehending" God as being male.

Outstanding piece.  Perhaps God is beyond our ability to totally comprehend.  Some of us feel His presence and His desire to relate with us, then use prayer as a means of growing that relationship.  Tolerance of wherever each of our neighbors is on their spiritual journey, or of their choice to renounce even the possibility of such a journey, might be in order.  The Hindus have a saying, ‘There are many paths to the Summit.’  Such a viewpoint is admirable in its humility.  Each of us feels comfortable with the path we’re taking, or we’d be on a different route.  However, the adage acknowledges that other paths might be just as meaningful and beneficial, perhaps even more so, than the one we’ve chosen to travel.  Those of us, like the author, who’ve chosen to relate in Love and acceptance with our neighbors, regardless of their spiritual beliefs or absence of them, aren’t trying to convert anyone to our way of thinking.  We’re just hoping to share a mindset and ‘heartset’ that have proven meaningful for us.
